title: Introduction to multibias
text: Represent observed data data_observed object. include dataframe, specify key variables data, identify bias impacting data. epidemiological biases can generalized four main groups: Uncontrolled confounding (uc) Exposure misclassificaiton (em) Outcome misclassificaiton (om) Selection bias (sel) Multibias capable handling bias adjustment combinations four biases. purposes demonstration, multibias includes datasets different bias combinations. given bias biases, includes biased data (e.g., df_uc_sel: missing confounder including un-selected subjects) source used derive biased data (e.g., df_uc_sel_source: including data missing confounder subjects selected). dataset variables defined similarly: X = binary exposure Y = binary outcome C1-C3 = binary confounders
code: df_observed <- data_observed(   df_uc_sel,   bias = c("uc", "sel"),   exposure = "X",   outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3") )

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Next, need information can used quantify assumed bias biases. two options .

title: Introduction to multibias
text: One option list assumed parameters corresponding bias equations. necessary bias equations provided documentation adjust() function. equations can derived using methods outlined article . example, bias parameters predict missing binary confounder U (vector u_coefs) study selection indicator S (vector s_coefs).

title: Introduction to multibias
text: second option specify validation data source data_validation object. order adjust given bias, validation data must corresonding missing data. example , validation data additional columns missing binary confounder U indicator S whether given individual selected study.
code: df_validation <- data_validation(   df_uc_sel_source,   true_exposure = "X",   true_outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3", "U"),   selection = "S" )

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Finally, can run multi-bias adjustment!

title: Introduction to multibias
text: observe bias-adjusted odds ratio effect X Y approximately 2. effect can compared effect observed biased data understand whether systematic error bringing observed effect closer null null.
code: multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   bias_params = bp ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.001141 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.948436 2.055271 multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   data_validation = df_validation ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.001603 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.948854 2.055779

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Multibias performs bias adjustment via combination imputation /regression weighting. imputation involved, inherent randomness sampling. single run, therefore, produce exactly consistent result unless seed specified. Bootstrapping thus recommended quantify random error. Computational performance can improved via parallelization. adjusting via bias parameters, user can alternatively provide bias parameter value probability distribution. resulting confidence interval bootstrapping can quantify uncertainty random error systematic error. Check vignette article “Multibias Validation” demonstration approach.
code: n <- nrow(df_uc_sel) est <- vector() nreps <- 100  for (i in 1:nreps) {   df_bootstrap <- df_uc_sel[sample(seq_len(n), n, replace = TRUE), ]   df_observed <- data_observed(     df_bootstrap,     bias = c("uc", "sel"),     exposure = "X",     outcome = "Y",     confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3")   )   results <- multibias_adjust(     df_observed,     df_validation   )   est[i] <- results$estimate }  # odds ratio estimate round(median(est), 2) #> [1] 2  # confidence interval round(quantile(est, c(.025, .975)), 2) #>  2.5% 97.5%  #>  1.94  2.06

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Epidemiologic studies often face multiple sources bias, including confounding, measurement error, selection bias. Investigators typically address biases speculating direction effect adjusting single source bias. multibias package provides framework simultaneously adjusting multiple sources bias. vignette demonstrates use multibias analyze relationship alcohol consumption mortality using data National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES). ’ll progressively add different types bias adjustments show affects estimates can combined comprehensive analysis.

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: demonstration, ’ll use 2013-2018 National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data linked CDC’s 2019 public-use mortality data. dataset provides rich source information including: Demographics 24-hour dietary recall Alcohol consumption patterns Smoking history Mortality outcomes

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: ’ll assessing risk alcohol intake -cause mortality, specifically comparing “extreme” drinkers “non-extreme” drinkers. Let’s first understand data create exposure variable.

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: ’ll anchor classification based US Dietary Guidelines Americans (USDGA) suggested limit: 14 g/day women 28 g/day men Participants classified “extreme drinkers” reported drinking 1.5x guidelines.
code: nhanes_filtered <- nhanes |>   mutate(alcohol_extreme = case_when(     alcohol_day_total > 14 * 1.5 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,     alcohol_day_total > 28 * 1.5 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,     TRUE ~ 0   )) |>   filter(age >= 18) |>   filter(eligstat == 1) |>   filter(alcohol_12mo > 0)

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Let’s examine key characteristics dataset:
code: exposure_outcome_table <- nhanes_filtered |>   group_by(alcohol_extreme, mortstat) |>   summarize(count = n()) |>   ungroup() |>   mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'alcohol_extreme'. You can override using #> the `.groups` argument.  # Distribution of Exposure and Outcome: print(exposure_outcome_table) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   alcohol_extreme mortstat count proportion #>             <dbl>    <int> <int>      <dbl> #> 1               0        0  8412    0.856   #> 2               0        1   281    0.0286  #> 3               1        0  1089    0.111   #> 4               1        1    44    0.00448  demographic_table <- nhanes_filtered |>   group_by(alcohol_extreme) |>   summarize(     n = n(),     age_mean = mean(age),     age_sd = sd(age),     gender_prop = mean(gender_female)   ) |>   mutate(     alcohol_extreme = if_else(       alcohol_extreme == 1, "Extreme", "Non-extreme"     )   )  # Demographic Characteristics by Exposure Status: print(demographic_table) #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   alcohol_extreme     n age_mean age_sd gender_prop #>   <chr>           <int>    <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 Non-extreme      8693     46.2   17.8       0.486 #> 2 Extreme          1133     45.1   15.8       0.454

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Let’s start basic logistic regression model estimate association extreme alcohol consumption mortality, adjusting age gender. serve reference point comparing bias-adjusted estimates. base model suggests extreme alcohol consumption associated 1.6-fold increase mortality risk (95% CI: 1.1, 2.2), adjusting age gender. However, estimate may biased due several factors ’ll address following sections.
code: base_mod <- glm(   mortstat ~ alcohol_extreme + gender_female + age,   data = nhanes_filtered,   family = binomial(link = "logit") )  base_results <- data.frame(   term = c("Extreme Alcohol Use", "Female Gender", "Age"),   estimate = round(exp(coef(base_mod)), 2)[-1],   ci_lower = round(exp(confint(base_mod)), 2)[-1, 1],   ci_upper = round(exp(confint(base_mod)), 2)[-1, 2] ) #> Waiting for profiling to be done... #> Waiting for profiling to be done...  # Base Model Results: Odds Ratios and 95% Confidence Intervals print(base_results) #>                                term estimate ci_lower ci_upper #> alcohol_extreme Extreme Alcohol Use     1.56     1.10     2.17 #> gender_female         Female Gender     0.68     0.54     0.86 #> age                             Age     1.09     1.08     1.10

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: ’ll now progressively adjust three types bias: Uncontrolled confounding (smoking status) Exposure misclassification (alcohol underreporting) Selection bias (NHANES sampling weights)

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Smoking strong confounder relationship alcohol consumption mortality. Smokers likely heavy drinkers, smoking independently increases mortality risk. base model didn’t account , potentially leading biased estimates. adjust bias , ’ll leverage validation dataset; fraction cohort patients, smoking information available.
code: # Create observed data object with uncontrolled confounding bias df_obs1 <- data_observed(   data = nhanes_filtered,   bias = "uc",   exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female") )  # Create validation data with smoking information df_temp1 <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs))  df_val1 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp1,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs") )  # Perform bias adjustment set.seed(1234) uc_adjusted <- multibias_adjust(df_obs1, df_val1)  # Uncontrolled Confounding Adjusted Results: print(uc_adjusted) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.411961 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.003703 1.986279

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Self-reported alcohol consumption often underreported due social stigma. ’ll adjust assuming certain demographic groups (wealthy, college-educated individuals) likely -report alcohol consumption.
code: # Create observed data object with both biases df_obs2 <- data_observed(   data = nhanes_filtered,   bias = c("em", "uc"),   exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female") )  # Create validation data with adjusted alcohol consumption df_temp2 <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs)) |>   mutate(     # Assume 50% higher consumption for high SES individuals     alcohol_adj = if_else(       income == "$100,000 and Over" | education == "College graduate or above",       alcohol_day_total * 1.5,       alcohol_day_total     )   ) |>   mutate(alcohol_extreme_adj = case_when(     alcohol_adj > 14 * 1.5 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,     alcohol_adj > 28 * 1.5 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,     TRUE ~ 0   ))  df_val2 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp2,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme_adj",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs"),   misclassified_exposure = "alcohol_extreme" )  # Perform bias adjustment set.seed(1234) uc_em_adjusted <- multibias_adjust(df_obs2, df_val2)  # Exposure Misclassification & Confounding Adjusted Results: print(uc_em_adjusted) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.139375 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.8177435 1.5875093

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: NHANES uses complex sampling design oversampling certain demographic groups. can create selection bias exposure (alcohol consumption) outcome (mortality) related selection probability. ’ll adjust using NHANES sampling weights.
code: # Create observed data object with all three biases df_obs3 <- data_observed(   data = nhanes_filtered,   bias = c("em", "uc", "sel"),   exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female") )  # Prepare data for selection bias adjustment df_temp3a <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs)) |>   mutate(     alcohol_adj = if_else(       income == "$100,000 and Over" | education == "College graduate or above",       alcohol_day_total * 1.5,       alcohol_day_total     ),     alcohol_extreme_adj = case_when(       alcohol_adj > 14 * 1.5 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,       alcohol_adj > 28 * 1.5 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,       TRUE ~ 0     ),     # Combine survey weights     weight = if_else(weight_day2 == 0, weight_day1, weight_day2)   )  # Create selection indicator based on sampling weights set.seed(1234) selected_sample <- sample(   x = df_temp3a$seqn,   size = nrow(df_temp3a),   replace = TRUE,   prob = df_temp3a$weight )  df_selected_sample <- data.frame() for (id in selected_sample) {   df_selected_sample <- rbind(     df_selected_sample,     df_temp3a[df_temp3a$seqn == id, ]   ) }  df_selected_sample$selection <- 1 df_not_selected_sample <- df_temp3a[!(df_temp3a$seqn %in% selected_sample), ] df_not_selected_sample$selection <- 0  df_temp3b <- rbind(df_selected_sample, df_not_selected_sample)  # Create validation data with selection information df_val3 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp3b,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme_adj",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs"),   misclassified_exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   selection = "selection" )  # Perform final bias adjustment set.seed(1234) final_adjusted <- multibias_adjust(df_obs3, df_val3)  # Triple Bias Adjusted Results: print(final_adjusted) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.178683 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.9150851 1.5182133

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: Let’s compare estimates see bias adjustment affects results:
code: # Create comparison table comparison_table <- data.frame(   Model = c(     "Base Model",     "Adjusted - Single Bias",     "Adjusted - Double Biases",     "Adjusted - Triple Biases"   ),   OR = c(     round(exp(coef(base_mod))["alcohol_extreme"], 2),     round(uc_adjusted$estimate, 2),     round(uc_em_adjusted$estimate, 2),     round(final_adjusted$estimate, 2)   ),   CI_lower = c(     round(exp(confint(base_mod))["alcohol_extreme", 1], 2),     round(uc_adjusted$ci[1], 2),     round(uc_em_adjusted$ci[1], 2),     round(final_adjusted$ci[1], 2)   ),   CI_upper = c(     round(exp(confint(base_mod))["alcohol_extreme", 2], 2),     round(uc_adjusted$ci[2], 2),     round(uc_em_adjusted$ci[2], 2),     round(final_adjusted$ci[2], 2)   ) ) #> Waiting for profiling to be done... #> Waiting for profiling to be done...  # Comparison of Bias-Adjusted Estimates: print(comparison_table) #>                      Model   OR CI_lower CI_upper #> 1               Base Model 1.56     1.10     2.17 #> 2   Adjusted - Single Bias 1.41     1.00     1.99 #> 3 Adjusted - Double Biases 1.14     0.82     1.59 #> 4 Adjusted - Triple Biases 1.18     0.92     1.52

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: analysis demonstrates multiple sources bias can affect estimated relationship alcohol consumption mortality: Uncontrolled Confounding: Adjusting smoking status reduced odds ratio 1.56 1.41, suggesting part observed association due confounding effect smoking. Exposure Misclassification: adjustment potential underreporting alcohol consumption reduced odds ratio 1.14, indicating measurement error may led overestimate true effect. Selection Bias: final adjustment NHANES sampling weights minimal impact estimate, suggesting selection bias may major concern analysis. results highlight importance considering multiple sources bias simultaneously. multibias package provides flexible framework analyses, allowing researchers incorporate various assumptions bias mechanisms assess impact study results.

code: @Manual{,   title = {multibias: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment},   author = {Paul Brendel},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.7, http://www.paulbrendel.com/multibias/},   url = {https://github.com/pcbrendel/multibias}, }

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
text: multibias package used adjust multiple biases causal inference working observational data. Bias refers case associational estimate effect equal causal estimate effect: (P(Y=1|X=1,C=0)/P(Y=1|X=0,C=0))≠(P(YX=1=1)/P(YX=0=1))(P(Y=1|X=1,C=0) / P(Y=1|X=0,C=0)) \neq (P(Y^{X=1}=1) / P(Y^{X=0}=1)) multibias_adjust() function outputs odds ratio estimates adjusted combination : uncontrolled confounding (uc), exposure misclassification (em), outcome misclassification (om), selection bias (sel). package also includes several dataframes useful validating bias adjustment methods. dataframe contains different combinations bias identified prefixing system. bias combination, dataframe incomplete information (encountered real world) (e.g., df_uc) dataframe complete information used derive biased data (e.g., df_uc_source).

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
code: # install from CRAN install.packages("multibias")  # install from github using devtools # library("devtools") devtools::install_github("pcbrendel/multibias")

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
text: Represent observed causal data data_observed object. provide data, specify key variables, list biases present data. See list different bias combinations multibias can handle. Bias parameters - via bias_params object. Values parameters come literature, validation data, expert opinion. parameter can represented single value probability distribution. See bias_params documentation full bias models. Validation dataframe - via data_validation object. purpose validation data use external data source transport necessary causal relationships missing observed data. Run multibias_adjust() using inputs obtain bias-adjusted exposure-outcome odds ratio confidence interval.

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
text: Single Bias exposure misclassification outcome misclassification selection bias uncontrolled confounding Multiple Biases exposure misclassification & selection bias exposure misclassification & outcome misclassification outcome misclassification & selection bias uncontrolled confounding & exposure misclassificaiton uncontrolled confounding & outcome misclassification uncontrolled confounding & selection bias uncontrolled confounding, exposure misclassification, & selection bias uncontrolled confounding, outcome misclassification, & selection bias

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
text: Brendel PB, Torres AZ, Arah OA, Simultaneous adjustment uncontrolled confounding, selection bias misclassification multiple-bias modelling, International Journal Epidemiology, Volume 52, Issue 4, Pages 1220–1230. https://doi.org/10.1093/ije/dyad001 Applying Quantitative Bias Analysis Epidemiologic Data

title: Represent bias parameters — bias_params
text: bias_params one two different options represent bias assumptions bias adjustment. multibias_adjust() function apply assumptions models use adjust biases observed data. takes one input, list, item list corresponds necessary models bias adjustment. See bias models. following bias models, variables defined: X = True exposure X* = Misclassified exposure Y = True outcome Y* = Misclassified outcome C = Known confounder j = Number known confounders U = Uncontrolled confounder S = Selection indicator Uncontrolled confounding logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y + α2+jCj Exposure misclassification logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj Outcome misclassification logit(P(Y=1)) = δ0 + δ1X + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj Selection bias logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y Uncontrolled Confounding & Exposure Misclassification (Option 1) logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y  logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding & Exposure Misclassification (Option 2) log(P(X=1,U=0)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X* + γ1,2Y + γ1,2+jCj log(P(X=0,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X* + γ2,2Y + γ2,2+jCj log(P(X=1,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X* + γ3,2Y + γ3,2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding & Outcome Misclassification (Option 1) logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y  logit(P(Y=1)) = δ0 + δ1X + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding & Outcome Misclassification (Option 2) log(P(U=1,Y=0)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X + γ1,2Y* + γ1,2+jCj log(P(U=0,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X + γ2,2Y* + γ2,2+jCj log(P(U=1,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X + γ3,2Y* + γ3,2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding & Selection Bias logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y + α2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y Exposure Misclassification & Outcome Misclassification (Option 1) logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj logit(P(Y=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y* + β2+jCj Exposure Misclassification & Outcome Misclassification (Option 2) log(P(X=1,Y=0) / P(X=0,Y=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X* + γ1,2Y* + γ1,2+jCj log(P(X=0,Y=1) / P(X=0,Y=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X* + γ2,2Y* + γ2,2+jCj log(P(X=1,Y=1) / P(X=0,Y=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X* + γ3,2Y* + γ3,2+jCj Exposure Misclassification & Selection Bias logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X* + β2Y + β2+jCj Outcome Misclassification & Selection Bias logit(P(Y=1)) = δ0 + δ1X + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y* + β2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding, Exposure Misclassification, Selection Bias (Option 1) logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y  logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X* + β2Y + β2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding, Exposure Misclassification, Selection Bias (Option 2) log(P(X=1,U=0)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X* + γ1,2Y + γ1,2+jCj log(P(X=0,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X* + γ2,2Y + γ2,2+jCj log(P(X=1,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X* + γ3,2Y + γ3,2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X* + β2Y + β2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding, Outcome Misclassification, Selection Bias (Option 1) logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y  logit(P(Y=1)) = δ0 + δ1X + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y* + β2+jCj Uncontrolled Confounding, Outcome Misclassification, Selection Bias (Option 2) log(P(U=1,Y=0)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X + γ1,2Y* + γ1,2+jCj log(P(U=0,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X + γ2,2Y* + γ2,2+jCj log(P(U=1,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X + γ3,2Y* + γ3,2+jCj logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y* + β2+jCj

title: Represent bias parameters — bias_params
text: coef_list List coefficient values options models. item list equation. left side equation identifies model (.e., "u" model predicting uncontrolled confounder). multinomial models, specify value based numerator (.e., "x1u0", "x0u1", "x1u1" three multinomial models Uncontrolled Confounding & Exposure Misclassification, Option 2) right side equation vector values corresponding model coefficients (left right).

title: Represent bias parameters — bias_params
code: list_for_uc <- list(   u = c(-0.19, 0.61, 0.70, -0.09, 0.10, -0.15) )  bp_uc <- bias_params(coef_list = list_for_uc)  list_for_em_om <- list(   x1y0 = c(-2.18, 1.63, 0.23, 0.36),   x0y1 = c(-3.17, 0.22, 1.60, 0.40),   x1y1 = c(-4.76, 1.82, 1.83, 0.72) )  bp_em_om <- bias_params(coef_list = list_for_em_om)

title: Represent observed causal data — data_observed
text: data_observed combines observed dataframe specific identification columns corresponding exposure, outcome, confounders. essential input multibias_adjust() function.

title: Represent observed causal data — data_observed
code: data_observed(data, bias, exposure, outcome, confounders = NULL)

title: Represent observed causal data — data_observed
text: data Dataframe bias analysis. bias String type(s) bias distorting effect exposure outcome. Can choose subset following: "uc", "em", "om", "sel". correspond uncontrolled confounding, exposure misclassification, outcome misclassification, selection bias, respectively. exposure String name column data corresponding exposure variable. outcome String name column data corresponding outcome variable. confounders String name(s) column(s) data corresponding confounding variable(s).

title: Represent observed causal data — data_observed
code: df <- data_observed(   data = df_sel,   bias = "uc",   exposure = "X",   outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3") )

title: Represent validation causal data — data_validation
text: data_validation one two different options represent bias assumptions bias adjustment. combines validation dataframe specific identification appropriate columns bias adjustment, including: true exposure, true outcome, confounders, misclassified exposure, misclassified outcome, selection. purpose validation data use external data source transport necessary causal relationships missing observed data.

title: Represent validation causal data — data_validation
code: data_validation(   data,   true_exposure,   true_outcome,   confounders = NULL,   misclassified_exposure = NULL,   misclassified_outcome = NULL,   selection = NULL )

title: Represent validation causal data — data_validation
text: data Dataframe validation data true_exposure String name column data corresponding true exposure. true_outcome String name column data corresponding true outcome. confounders String name(s) column(s) data corresponding confounding variable(s). misclassified_exposure String name column data corresponding misclassified exposure. misclassified_outcome String name column data corresponding misclassified outcome. selection String name column data corresponding selection indicator.

title: Represent validation causal data — data_validation
code: df <- data_validation(   data = df_sel_source,   true_exposure = "X",   true_outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3"),   selection = "S" )

what: Simulated data with exposure misclassification — df_em
title: Simulated data with exposure misclassification — df_em
text: Data containing one source bias, three known confounders, 100,000 observations. data obtained df_emc_source removing column X. resulting data corresponds researcher see real-world: misclassified exposure, Xstar, data true exposure. seen df_emc_source, true, unbiased exposure-outcome odds ratio = 2.

title: Simulated data with exposure misclassification — df_em
Simulated data with exposure misclassification — df_em
text: dataframe 100,000 rows 5 columns: Xstar misclassified exposure, 1 = present 0 = absent Y outcome, 1 = present 0 = absent C1 1st confounder, 1 = present 0 = absent C2 2nd confounder, 1 = present 0 = absent C3 3rd confounder, 1 = present 0 = absent

title: Simulated data with exposure misclassification and outcome misclassification — df_em_om
text: Data containing two sources bias, three known confounders, 100,000 observations. data obtained df_emc_omc_source removing columns X Y. resulting data corresponds researcher see real-world: misclassified exposure, Xstar, misclassified outcome, Ystar. seen df_em_om_source, true, unbiased exposure-outcome odds ratio = 2.

title: Simulated data with exposure misclassification and outcome misclassification — df_em_om

title: multibias: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment — multibias-package
text: Quantify causal effect binary exposure binary outcome adjustment multiple biases. functions can simultaneously adjust combination uncontrolled confounding, exposure/outcome misclassification, selection bias. underlying method generalizes concept combining inverse probability selection weighting predictive value weighting. Simultaneous multi-bias analysis can used enhance validity transparency real-world evidence obtained observational, longitudinal studies. Based work Paul Brendel, Aracelis Torres, Onyebuchi Arah (2023) doi:10.1093/ije/dyad001 .

title: multibias: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment — multibias-package
text: Maintainer: Paul Brendel pcbrendel@gmail.com [copyright holder]

what: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
text: multibias_adjust returns exposure-outcome odds ratio confidence interval, adjusted one biases.

title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
code: multibias_adjust(   data_observed,   data_validation = NULL,   bias_params = NULL,   level = 0.95 )

title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
text: data_observed Object class data_observed corresponding data perform bias analysis . data_validation Object class data_validation corresponding validation data used adjust bias observed data. validation data data variables data_observed, plus data missing variables leading bias. bias_params Object class 'bias_params' corresponding bias parameters used adjust bias observed data. must parameters corresponding bias biases specified data_observed. level Value 0-1 representing full range confidence interval. Default 0.95.

title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
text: list first item odds ratio estimate effect exposure outcome second item confidence interval vector: (lower bound, upper bound).

title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
text: Bias adjustment can performed inputting either validation dataset necessary bias parameters. Values bias parameters can applied fixed values single draws probability distribution (ex: rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 1)). latter advantage allowing researcher capture uncertainty bias parameter estimates. incorporate uncertainty estimate confidence interval, function run loop across bootstrap samples dataframe analysis. estimate confidence interval obtained median quantiles distribution odds ratio estimates.

title: Simultaneously adjust for multiple biases — multibias_adjust
code: # Adjust for exposure misclassification ------------------------------------- df_observed <- data_observed(   data = df_em,   bias = "em",   exposure = "Xstar",   outcome = "Y",   confounders = "C1" )  # Using validation data df_validation <- data_validation(   data = df_em_source,   true_exposure = "X",   true_outcome = "Y",   confounders = "C1",   misclassified_exposure = "Xstar" )  multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   data_validation = df_validation ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.123305 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 2.041413 2.208482 #>   # Using bias_params bp <- bias_params(coef_list = list(x = c(-2.10, 1.62, 0.63, 0.35)))  multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   bias_params = bp ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.050886 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.971682 2.133272 #>   # Adjust for three biases --------------------------------------------------- df_observed <- data_observed(   data = df_uc_om_sel,   bias = c("uc", "om", "sel"),   exposure = "X",   outcome = "Ystar",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3") )  # Using validation data df_validation <- data_validation(   data = df_uc_om_sel_source,   true_exposure = "X",   true_outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3", "U"),   misclassified_outcome = "Ystar",   selection = "S" )  multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   data_validation = df_validation ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.051169 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.998335 2.105399 #>   # Using bias_params bp1 <- bias_params(   coef_list = list(     u = c(-0.32, 0.59, 0.69),     y = c(-2.85, 0.71, 1.63, 0.40, -0.85, 0.22),     s = c(0.00, 0.74, 0.19, 0.02, -0.06, 0.02)   ) )  multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   bias_params = bp1 ) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.992133 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.940813 2.044810 #>   bp2 <- bias_params(   coef_list = list(     u1y0 = c(-0.20, 0.62, 0.01, -0.08, 0.10, -0.15),     u0y1 = c(-3.28, 0.63, 1.65, 0.42, -0.85, 0.26),     u1y1 = c(-2.70, 1.22, 1.64, 0.32, -0.77, 0.09),     s = c(0.00, 0.74, 0.19, 0.02, -0.06, 0.02)   ) )  multibias_adjust(   data_observed = df_observed,   bias_params = bp2 ) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.994691 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.943281 2.047462 #>

title: multibias 1.7
text: Created bias_params class handle bias parameter inputs multibias_adjust() Replaced various adjust() functions single multibias_adjust() function. Users now specify biases want adjust data_observed object. Bias adjustment formulas now found bias_params documentation. user now specifies biases adjustment bias input data_observed Removed evans data; now used vignette
